response.answer_text: Albert Einstein built an entire theory, called special relativity, around the idea that the speed of light is the same for everyone who measures it, no matter how fast they are moving in relation to the light. In order to accommodate this behavior for light, Einstein’s theory predicted that time and space would have to stretch or contract as someone traveled with increasing speed. And out of special relativity popped a cosmic speed limit: nothing could ever exceed the speed of light.Relativity is a cornerstone of all of modern physics, and we have no reason to doubt it – no one has ever observed an object moving faster than light. There’s actually a minor clarification necessary here: Einstein’s speed limit is the speed of light in a vacuum. Light slows down when it moves through a material like water or glass, and then it’s perfectly possible to exceed this reduced speed of light – up to its speed in a vacuum, of course. Anything moving faster than light in water or glass produces the luminous equivalent of a sonic boom, called Čerenkov radiation. It’s what gives underwater nuclear reactors their attractive blue glow.But About that Warp Drive… Of all of the attempts to wiggle out of Einstein’s speed limit, probably the most plausible is theoretical physicist Miguel Alcubierre’s “warp drive”. Alcubierre’s proposal doesn’t violate the cosmic speed limit – it goes around it. Try filling a greasy frying pan with water and then put a drop of soap into the pan. The grease will fly away to the sides of the pan.  Alcubierre’s warp drive does the same thing with space itself. Alcubierre showed that by a suitable distribution of matter, you can shrink space in front of your spaceship and stretch it behind the spaceship, creating a small bubble around the ship that moves as fast as you like. Because space is contracting in front of the ship, the ship wouldn’t officially be moving faster than the speed of light. In fact, the ship would actually be at rest relative to the warp bubble, and the people inside the ship wouldn’t even feel any acceleration. Talk about a smooth ride!

If you travel at 99.5% of the speed of light, departing on 25 December 2015 for 5 years in a circular route and return to Earth, you will only have aged 5 years, but everyone else on Earth will have aged 50 years and the date will be 25 December 2065. You have therefore traveled into the future. If you traveled in a straight line, you will have reached a point 50 light years away from earth. For the crew on the space ship, they would have experienced travel at 10 times the speed of light. So according to them, they traveled faster than light. You cannot reach the speed of light since you have mass, as explained hundreds of times on Quora in different posts. Unless we develop technology like the Alcubierre drive, we will always have relativistic time dilation effects and large discrepancies between the time experienced by our space ship crews and the rest of humanity remaining on Earth. Look at it this way: When you travel in space, the faster you go, the more energy you have to exert on your space ship to increase your speed. Approaching the speed of light, your relativistic mass (or momentum) increases quadratically. For you as an observer on your space ship, you are stationary and the rest of the universe is flying past you at close to the speed of light. To accelerate faster, you have to increase the speed of the entire universe, with its mass, to go faster. That is clearly impossible. That is why, for velocities to ever approach c (light speed), you will have to create a bubble around your space ship that is totally removed from the rest of the universe and that bubble will now be your entire universe. Then it becomes more feasible to consider accelerating that small portion of space by bending space around that bubble, but your space ship inside it actually remains stationary. Therein lies the problem. To "bend space around your bubble" by contracting the space in front of and expanding space behind your private space bubble to create a wave to then race into the future, will require an incredible amount of energy. The best current models require an engine and ship manufactured from exotic matter with negative mass as well as energy equivalent to the 100% efficient conversion of 700 kg of mass directly to energy. Those two factors alone require technologies that are possibly still centuries away from being developed, managed and controlled. I wish it was not so. I am as passionate as you seem to be about the possibility of the human race upgrading to a true spacefaring species. The technological hurdles are vast though. I will cheer with you as soon as an alternative method of traveling to the stars is found and our first interstellar space ship is launched.

Humans will indeed travel at the speed of light - digitized.  You are not the same atoms you were years ago - many get replaced over time, while you remain. How many bits does it take to faithfully copy a human?  A bunch.  How much energy is needed to represent all that?  The greatest possible energy amount is the food energy you've consumed over your lifetime, since that was sufficient to make all your cells and make all your synapses and memories.  2000 calories a day for 50 years is 50 kilowatt hours, about $5.00 worth of electricity, or enough energy to move a 70 kilogram person up to 20% of earth escape velocity at 100% efficiency. It is more complicated, of course - a neural "bit"  is about 20,000 electron volts (a very small unit of energy), while a bit at room temperature can be transmitted with about 20 milli-electron volts.  We can  (in principle) move the bits in your brain a million times more efficiently with technology rather than with meat.  While you have more than one genome in your body (the genes get modified and methylated as you grow, and there are vastly more chromosomes and genes in the bacteria in your gut), these data sets are mostly alike and can be "compressed".   Probably all that data can be compressed without losses by another factor of a billion.  The result could be used to build a molecularly accurate copy of you.   On the other hand, if we transmit your bits to a distant star, we will need some very large, very accurately made, very accurately pointed transmission and receive dishes - and even with those, we must transmit quintillions of times more power than will be captured by the receiver at the other end.  So we are back to needing "lots" of energy - perhaps thousands of dollars worth.    But how much energy would it take to send you surrounded by a minaturized biosphere to keep you alive to the stars?   Your fraction of the global biomass (plants and animals and microbes) is about 80 metric tons of carbon - assume your share of starship biomass and water and air and equipment support is about a thousand tons (much smaller than your Spaceship Earth support mass of about a trillion tons).   Assume you have a 100% efficient electromagnetic accelerator launching you towards the stars at 90% of the speed of light.   That will require about 20 billion gigawatt hours, about 200 years of global production at current rates;  quite a bit more than thousands of dollars worth of electricity.  For just you, not your crewmates (though most of the "crew" will be frozen zygotes).   A one gee accelerator would need to be 4 trillion kilometers long - about 0.4 light years - and it would have to be aligned to within micrometers, or the sideways vibrations would smash you to jelly.  And of course, you will need a slowdown track at the other end. I won't even bother to compute the energy needed for a rocket (presumably powered by matter and antimatter) constrained by the Tsiolkovskii exponential rocket formula - my calculator only does 2 digit exponents. So yes, if we go at all, we will go as bits, probably preceded by a wave of slow von Neumann replicator robots building receivers at the far end.  Meat bodies are fragile, and few survive past a century - you die with a fraction of the neurons you were born with, few or no replacements (we know this because of neuron DNA isotope ratios of autopsied human brains born before, during, or after the years of above-ground nuclear testing).  So if you want to live long enough to go to a distant star with a shirtsleeve planetary system (unlike the thousands of hellholes imaged by Kepler) you must recopy your brain digitally, one way or another.  You may want to store your mind as bits for a few kiloyears anyway, while all the equipment is built and deployed.

Having mass, humans can never travel at the speed of light, nothing with mass can. However, there is nothing in the laws of physics which prevents an object with mass, including us, from traveling as close to the speed of light as we can technologically manage it. The most important technological barrier to such travel is of course the development of a power plant capable of achieving those speeds. There is also a problem of induced radiation by free protons in the depths of space. These free protons would be traveling at 99.9999% the speed of light relative to the spaceship. There would have to be some kind of shielding required to keep those protons from zipping through the spaceship and the bodies of the crew, which would kill them. Questions like this often generate answers which describe near lightspeed travel and how much a person engaged in that travel would age compared to those people that were left behind. For further information you can read about the Twin Paradox. It is a thought experiment in which there are two twins, and one of them goes on a near lightspeed journey out into space and returns to Earth. The traveling twin has aged very little while the earthbound twin has aged very much. This thought experiment takes into account the acceleration of the spacecraft departing, turning around, and slowing down to get back to Earth. But rarely have I seen this acceleration accounted for in a way that deals with the health of the crew, as regards the acceleration forces upon the them. So here is what a near lightspeed journey would actually require to preserve the health, even the life, of the crew. Acceleration in a vehicle is measured as G forces. The force of gravity here on the surface of the Earth is 1G. It is what we live with, it is what we are accustomed to, and it is what our bodies have a evolved to live with. A force of two G’s, for example, would cause your body to feel as though it weighed twice as much as it actually does on the surface of the Earth. That’s not a problem for limited periods of time, in fact human beings can withstand seven or eight G’s for limited periods of time. But a force of two G’s, over an extremely long period of time, would most certainly be detrimental to the crew of a spaceship accelerating enough to create that strength of force. This means that a space vehicle intended to travel at very close to the speed of light, would have to accelerate up to that speed so that the crew experienced 1G, in other words the same force experienced here on earth. Let us assume that a vehicle is capable of traveling 99.9999% the speed of light. The vehicle departs and begins the long, slow process of acceleration up to the its near lightspeed capability . It would take about 12 years to accelerate up to that very great speed while maintaining a force of 1G on the crew. By the time that 12 years has gone by, the ship will have traveled about 113,000 light years. The vessel would already have exited the Milky Way galaxy. Let’s assume that deceleration occurs very soon after the ship reaches its top speed. It would take another 12 years to decelerate to a speed which would make reentry into a planet’s atmosphere feasible. That means another 113,000 lightyears has been traveled by the spaceship. The crew would have aged approximately 24 years. Those left behind on earth are long gone, as 126,000 years will have passed. If the journey was a round-trip, the vessel would require the deceleration from near light speed down to a speed in which a turnaround could be executed without having to describe an enormous half circle to do so. It would then take another 12 years to accelerate, and finally another 12 years to decelerate down to a manageable speed in order to re-enter Earth’s atmosphere. The crew will have aged a minimum of 48 years during such a journey, while the Earth would have aged a total of approximately 252,000 years. An interesting thing will have happened while the vessel was gone: the earth would’ve made one complete revolution around the center of the Milky Way galaxy during the time the spaceship was gone, because it takes approximately 1/4 billion years to make that revolution. Have a safe trip.

I'm going to answer this question in three parts, because I think there are unstated assumptions and implications in the original question. First, I assume the question is whether a spacecraft can be built and operated to safely transport a human to a distant location and back again. I am going to treat “ever” as “within 200 years” because I think 200 years is longer than anyone could reasonably be expected to extrapolate current knowledge and technology in any field. So, the three parts are: 1. Can we build a spacecraft that can travel at a significant fraction of the speed of light, say, within 90 percent? 2. Can we build a spacecraft that can travel at exactly the speed of light? 3. Can we build a spacecraft that can travel at faster than the speed of light? The answer to the first question is maybe. It is an extremely difficult problem because of the difficulty of accelerating a massive object to very high speeds. The fastest object we have put into space is the Juno mission, which reached about 0.013 percent of the speed of light. Accelerating a spacecraft with the mass necessary to carry a human and all the required support equipment to a speed more than 5000 times the speed of Juno would be a daunting task. The energy alone is more than any current technology could provide, and we are currently unable to make technology reliable enough to support a human for the duration. We also don't have the technology to protect a spacecraft from impacts with anything it might hit, like a little piece of rock the size of a grain of sand. At that speed, the energy released by such an impact would be devastating. However, it is just possibly imaginable that we could develop current technology to the point that it would be possible to travel at very high speeds, possibly approaching 90 percent of the speed of light. But I doubt it. The answer to the second question is definitely no; we won't be able to travel at the speed of light, or even within a fraction of a percent. We don't have the means to accelerate a massive object to that speed, and there is no reason to expect that we ever will. Actually reaching the speed of light would pose what appear to be insoluble physical problems, so I think we can discount that possibility. You may be aware that the mass of an object increases as it is accelerated towards the speed of light. That means that the energy required to accelerate it increases as well. In the real world, the laws of physics mean that the closer you get to the speed of light, the harder it gets to go any faster. The answer to the third question is also no. There appears to be some means not excluded by the currently known laws of physics that might allow travel that appears to exceed the speed of light but actually does not. The effect would be that a traveler could reach a distant point in less time than it would take light to reach that point, but because the technology involves warping space, the actual speed would not exceed the speed of light. However, there is a difference between something that does not violate known physical principles and something that can actually be done. Sometimes the laws of physics are so stringent that achieving the physically possibly is not physically practical. In this case, the energy that would apparently be required to do the space warping is so great that there is no physically practical way to provide it, even assuming very favorable technology developments. It also appears that this method would require things that appear not to be physically possible. So, even though some people discuss it as if it were possible, it really doesn’t appear to be possible. Even for the "maybe" answer, I would not place any large bets on our ability to do it.

At that point, your mass would be infinite (which is impossible) and the energy it would take to get you there would be infinite (also impossible).  So no, you can't travel at the speed of light. As you might well know, it's not possible to travel at the speed of light, according to Einstein's equation. The speed of light is not really a fixed speed (in a manner of speaking), it's sort of like a boundary, one that constantly adjusts to match your speed. Here's something to think about. Supposing you were standing on a platform observing a ball being bounced inside a train on it's wall. As the ball moves forward from the person, it would have a velocity V from both your perspective and that of the thrower. Now supposing the train starts moving in the direction of the throw, the thrower still observes a velocity V whilst you would now observe a velocity W = V + V1, where V1 is the velocity of the train. Now instead of a ball, replace that with a beam of light. Intuitively, you'd expect that when the train starts moving, the person on the train with the beam would observe the speed of light to be C and you would observe a C + V1, but not so, you'd both observe the same speed C. Come to think of it, it's sort of like trying to catch up with the horizon. No matter how fast one might travel, it would always be ahead of you. Now, let's even suppose that we could infact travel at the speed of light. Usually in an enclosed environment, you would not be aware of the speed at which you are moving relative to objects that are outside the enclosing environment. For example, we are not aware that the earth on which we live is moving, nor that the solar system itself is moving, nor that the galaxy is moving, and so on up to the universe itself and whatever contains the universe :) So in essence, so long the craft you are traveling in can weather the strain, then you are fine, but you'd definitely not expect to survive if you were hurled at the speed of light into space without any protection. Just as a side note.Unless new theories come up that either expose a wholly new side to the theories of relativity, I suspect that space travel will not be accomplished via FTL travel, but probably by using other techniques that would bend or warp space-time or create temporal wormholes to connect distant regions of space.

You have to define what it means to travel at the speed of light.  Let's say you are in a foot race with a beam of light. The starting gun fires, and you take off at your sprinting speed. According to the second postulate of relativity, all inertial observers measure the speed of light as c. That means someone standing at the starting line will observe the light beam move to the finish line at c. It means that you too, while sprinting, will observe the light beam move off at c. Let's say the light beam gives you a small head start. From your perspective, the beam of light passes you at c. So the light beam always matches your speed, and then adds c to its own velocity. You increase your speed, and  (to you) the light beam increases it's speed accordingly. So the issue is not that you can't match the beam of light, it's that you can't even get beyond 0% of the light beam's speed.  Note that by a stopwatch which you carry, there is no minimum constraint on how 'fast' you can complete the race, fast here in the sense of 'less time'. No matter what time you finish the race, you can always do the race again 'faster' and achieve a better (less) time, by a stopwatch you carry with you.  But of course, the light beam always passes you at c, so no matter how little you race completion time is, the light beam's is always less (no head start anymore for you), and it always wins the race  (reaches the finish line first). So you can go as fast as you like, you just can't go faster than light.  Naturally, an observer at the finish line will agree that the light beam finishes first: different observers may disagree about the sequence of events at points separated in space-time, but they will all agree on the sequence of events at a single point in space.  Let's say the race track is 10 light minutes long, as measured by a tape measure stretched from the starting line to the finishing line. That means to an observer on the sidelines, the race always lasts exactly 10 minutes, since light always wins. In other words, prior to the race, identical clocks are set up at the start and finish lines, and light signals are exchanged to synchronize them. So if an observer near one clock notes the time as 12:10, through a telescope the other clock would read 12:00. If the race is scheduled to start at 3:00 pm, observers near the start line will see you and the light beam take off when that clock reads 3:00, and observers near the finish line will see the light beam cross the finish line when that clock reads 3:10. The finish line clock will always read some time after 3:10 when you cross the finish line.  So to observers on the sidelines, the distance is 10 light minutes and your time is more than 10 minutes, so your speed is always less than c. But remember, by your stopwatch, you can complete the race in as little time as you like. So let's say you complete the race and your stopwatch reads 1 minute. Observers on the side lines will agree your clock only ticked off 1 minute during the race  (cameras at the start and finish lines can capture your clock and the start/finish line clock to verify).  Observers on the sidelines will conclude your clock runs slow.  [Note that you will agree with all these clock readings. But by relatively theory, from your perspective  the clocks at the start and finish lines should run slow compared to your own. If you took careful measurements, you would conclude the start and finish line clocks are not synchronized, so they don't fairly measure the time elapsed on your stopwatch.] So if you think you finished a 10 light minute long race track in 1 minute, does that mean you traveled faster than c? If you completed the race in 1 minute, since light always wins, it must have completed the race in less than a minute. That means to you, the race track can't be 10 light minutes long, it has to be less than a light minute long. So the measuring tape stretched from start to finish lines has apparently contracted.  So everyone ultimately agrees you never travel faster than c, even though you and the people on the sidelines disagree on just about everything else. No you can’t. But not only can you go speeds that are arbitrarily close to the speed of light, in fact, you already are. To explain: if you take to heart the founding principles of relativity, you understand that there is no preferred reference frame. A reference frame is can be thought of as a non-rotating set of axes in space - though not rotating, it can be moving with constant speed and direction. You measure the velocity of a thing by looking at its motion relative to a reference frame. There are as many reference frames as there are speeds that you can go, and directions that you can go in. In each one of them, you have a different speed and/or direction. And so here is the very interesting result you get when you fully understand this: you are already going as fast as you can possibly go. In fact, you are already going every speed that is less than the speed of light. In some reference frames, you are going 99.99999% of the speed of light. In some, you're going even closer to the speed of light. But in none of them are you actually going at the speed of light. Why do I say that? Well, the theory of relativity says that light is measured as having the same speed in every reference frame. Which means that light is measured at less than the speed of light in none of them. So you can either be going the speed of light, or you can simultaneously be going all speeds that are less than the speed of light. You can't mix those - you can go the speed of light in either no reference frames, or in all of them. And you can go less than the speed of light in either no reference frames, or in all of them. And if it's less, then you're going all speeds that are less. So with all this in mind, you can realize that no matter how fast you go, you never actually get any closer to traveling at the speed of light, because you're always going all speeds that are less than it.

response.answer_text: Based on all physical possibilities that we currently know, the answer is no. But obviously this answer is no fun.  So let's speculate on any way that is compatible with what we currently know about the universe that would allow us to get around it. It is possible for things that do not actually involve the transfer of actual energy to travel faster than the speed of light.  For example, interference fringes or shadows.  This doesn't seem very helpful, since even if you set up a totally coherent beam of light, that the cast shadow of an astronaut on a distant astronomical body could move faster than the speed of light, doesn't seem to help the space program very much! However, in general relativity, it is possible for a region of space to move faster than the speed of light, and very high rates of space-time expansion are associated with the theory of cosmic inflation.  The local stuff inside that region of space does not violate the rules, and it is still limited by the light barrier. So the question, first raised in the 1990's was, was there any way you could construct a stable region of space-time that moved independently, but in which objects in the interior would not feel any G-force, or be torn apart by tidal forces?  Now in general relativity, any possible configuration of space-time is associated with a particular distribution of mass and energy, so we'd also have to determine what that is. It turns out there is a solution to the Einstein field equations, called the Alcubierre metric.  It does exist, and it seems to predict that a ship placed in the center of this theoretical distorted region of space-time would be unharmed, and that region would be capable of reaching unlimited speeds.  It is, however, essentially science fiction with math.  The energy requirements to create such a region appear to be astronomical, on the order of converting the mass of Jupiter to energy, and worse yet the energy density to pull it off has to be negative! Strictly speaking, there are specialized states that can have negative energy, but this tells us that if were ever to construct such a thing it is far beyond our current capabilities, and requires exotic matter, which, although predicted by some current cosmological models, cannot be manufactured by any known process.  To be a little more optimistic, there have been some studies that suggest that the amount of energy may be less than originally thought.   For more information on this topic: Alcubierre drive.
